head.title: A GPS-based method to model the plasma effects in VLBI observations

meta.name: keywords
meta.content: Plasmas – Atmospheric effects – Methods: observational – Techniques: interferometric – Astrometry

article.h1: A GPS-based method to model the plasma effects in VLBI observations

span.span: 1 Departament d’Astronomia i Astrofísica, Universitat de València, E-46100 Burjassot, València, Spain 12Max-Planck-Institut für Radioastronomie, Auf dem Hügel 69, D-53121 Bonn, Germany 2
1 Departament d’Astronomia i Astrofísica, Universitat de València, E-46100 Burjassot, València, Spain 1
1 Departament d’Astronomia i Astrofísica, Universitat de València, E-46100 Burjassot, València, Spain 1

Present address: Grupo de Mecánica del Vuelo S.A., Isaac Newton 11, PTM Tres Cantos, E-27860 Madrid, Spain3Deutsche Forschungsanstalt für Luft- und Raumfahrt e.V., Fernerkundungstation Neustrelitz, D-17235 Neustrelitz, Germany 3
4Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, 60 Garden St., Cambridge, MA 02138, US 4

div.p: Global Positioning System (GPS) satellites broadcast at frequencies of 1,575.42 MHz (L1) and of 1,227.60 MHz (L2). The dispersive property of the ionosphere can be used to combine independent measurements at the two frequencies to estimate the total electron content (TEC) between a GPS receiver site and a broadcasting satellite. Such measurements, made at sites near to Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) sites, can be used to estimate the ionospheric contribution to VLBI observables. For our 1991.9 astrometric VLBI experiment in which we obtained group-delay observations in the 8.4 and 2.3 GHz bands simultaneously, we found that the GPS and VLBI determinations of the ionosphere delays agreed with root-mean-square differences below 0.15 ns for intercontinental baselines and 0.10 ns for continental ones. We also successfully applied the GPS-based procedure to reduce the ionospheric effect in phase delays used for high precision differenced astrometry at 8.4 GHz for this same experiment.

article.div: Key Words.:Plasmas – Atmospheric effects – Methods: observational – Techniques: interferometric – Astrometry

div.p: VLBI provides unprecedentedly accurate angular resolution through observations of celestial bodies with radio telescopes spread over the Earth’s surface. Each observing station records data on magnetic tapes. The local-oscillator signals and the time-tagging of the data are governed by hydrogen-maser frequency standards. The tapes are processed in special-purpose correlators to determine the so-called VLBI observables: group and phase delays and phase-delay rates.

A main problem in determining the sky positions of celestial radio sources from these VLBI observables is the effect of the Earth’s ionosphere on them. The use of GPS satellite data to remove this effect forms the thrust of this paper.

The ionosphere is characterized by its content of free electrons and ions. The F22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2} layer of the ionosphere has the largest density of charged particles, with values up to 3×10123superscript1012NUMBER:3 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:12 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end3\times 10^{12} m-33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-3}. The total electron content per square meter along a line of sight is the number of electrons in a column of one square meter cross section along the ray path:

semantics.annotation: TEC RELOP:equals INTOP:integral POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-N MULOP:cdot italic-d italic-h PUNCT:,

div.p: where N𝑁italic-NN is the spatial density of electrons, hℎitalic-hh is the coordinate of propagation of the wave, and h0subscriptℎ0italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endh_{0} corresponds to the effective end of the ionosphere. TEC is highly variable and depends on several factors, such as local time, geographical location, season, and solar activity. TEC can have values between 1 TECU (or TEC unit, defined as 101616FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:16 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{16} m-22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-2}) and 1033FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{3} TECU. Epochs of greater solar activity cause higher values of the TEC.
The ionosphere affects the phase and group delays oppositely (to first order, see, e.g., Thompson et al. tho86 ):

semantics.annotation: Delta italic-tau RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus-or-plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-kappa ARG:end ARG:start italic-c italic-nu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARG:end MULOP:cdot TEC PUNCT:,

div.p: where κ≈40.3𝜅40.3italic-kappa RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:40.3\kappa\approx 40.3 m33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{3}s-22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-2}, c𝑐italic-cc is the speed of light (m⋅⋅MULOP:cdot\cdots-11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-1}), and ν𝜈italic-nu\nu the frequency (Hz), and where we neglect magnetic field effects and assume ν𝜈italic-nu\nu is large compared with the local plasma frequency (for an extreme case, the plasma frequency is of ∼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim15 MHz). The negative sign applies for phase delays and the positive sign for group delays. In standard astrometric VLBI experiments observations are made simultaneously in two well separated bands of frequencies in order to estimate the ionospheric effect. A nearly vacuum equivalent delay can be obtained from the following expression:

semantics.annotation: italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start free POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start OPEN:( italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start OPEN:( italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 ARG:end PUNCT:,

div.p:
where τisubscript𝜏𝑖italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end	au_{i} is the delay –either group or phase– at frequency νisubscript𝜈𝑖italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
u_{i} (i=1,2𝑖12italic-i RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2i=1,2, ν1>ν2subscript𝜈1subscript𝜈2italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
u_{1}>
u_{2}).

Thus, with dual frequency observations, the ionosphere effect can largely be removed from the VLBI data. Such removal can also be made for single-frequency observations via Eq. (2), if estimates of the TEC along the lines of sight of the radio telescopes are available from other observations.

Guirado et al. (gui95 ) showed that it is possible to estimate the ionospheric effect with accuracy useful for astrometric purposes from Faraday-rotation measurements. In this work, the authors used a “clipped” sinusoidal function to model the diurnal behavior of the TEC. In this model, the night component is constant and equal to the minimum TEC value, and the day component is expressed as the positive part of a sinusoid, with its maximum some hours after noon. Their observations were obtained in late 1985, a time of minimum solar activity.

In the method presented here we used GPS measurements that provide TEC values as a function of time. Such GPS-based TEC determinations were first successfully applied to geodetic VLBI by Sardón et al. (sar92 ).

section.h2: 2 The Global Positioning System and the TEC.

div.p: An introduction to the Global Positioning System (GPS) can be found in Hofmann-Wellenhof et al. (hof97 ). A main use of the GPS system is to determine the position (x,y,z,t)𝑥𝑦𝑧𝑡OPEN:( italic-x PUNCT:, italic-y PUNCT:, italic-z PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:)(x,y,z,t) of a GPS receiver on Earth’s surface. The system consists of a constellation of 24 satellites broadcasting electromagnetic signals in two narrow frequency bands, a set of monitoring ground sites, the Master Control Station, and GPS receivers. The 24 satellites orbit the Earth in near circular orbits with a 12 hr period, at a height of about 20,200 km, and an inclination of 55∘FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{\circ}. The spacecraft are in six orbital planes with four satellites nearly equally spaced along the orbit in each plane. At any moment, from any point on Earth, it is possible to detect signals simultaneously from 7 to 9 of these satellites. Each satellite broadcasts a block of data every 30 seconds, consisting of a description of its orbit and of GPS time, as well as a pseudo-random code every millisecond (coarse-acquisition C/A, for civilian use) and a precision code (P, 266 d period, for military use), usable to determine more accurately the position of the ground receiver.

The oscillators of the satellites generate a fundamental frequency ν0=10.23subscript𝜈010.23italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:10.23
u_{0}=10.23 MHz, which is the P-code frequency. The C/A-code frequency is ν0/10subscript𝜈010italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:10
u_{0}/10. The GPS signal is emitted at two frequencies, 154 ν0subscript𝜈0italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
u_{0} and 120 ν0subscript𝜈0italic-nu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
u_{0} (L1 and L2, respectively, 1,575.42 MHz and 1,227.60 MHz, or λ⁢λ𝜆𝜆italic-lambda italic-lambda\lambda\lambda19 and 24.4 cm). L2 carries only the P signal, and L1 both P and C/A signals.

The main GPS observable is d⁢T𝑑𝑇italic-d italic-TdT, the time of transit of the signal from the satellite to the ground receiver. The value of d⁢T𝑑𝑇italic-d italic-TdT can be determined, in effect, by comparing the time of broadcasting of the codes P or C/A with the time of receipt of these codes. An observable that corresponds to d⁢T𝑑𝑇italic-d italic-TdT can be obtained by cross correlation of the signal received from the satellite at each band with a reference signal generated at the receiver and “tied” to GPS time. In this case, d⁢T=ϕ/2⁢π⁢ν𝑑𝑇italic-ϕ2𝜋𝜈italic-d italic-T RELOP:equals italic-phi MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 italic-pi italic-nudT=\phi/2\pi\nu, where ϕitalic-ϕitalic-phi\phi is the total phase change of the signal during propagation from satellite to receiver and ν𝜈italic-nu\nu is the center frequency of this transmitted signal. This observable is the phase delay of the carrier signal.

The GPS observable is affected by the following: the ionosphere, the troposphere, 2⁢π2𝜋NUMBER:2 italic-pi2\pi phase ambiguities (equivalent to multiples of of 634.75 ps and 814.60 ps, respectively, for L1 and L2), multipath (e.g., from signals that are reflected or scattered into the receiver antennas from objects nearby to it), different effective location of receivers for L1 and L2, instrumental delays (different for L1 and L2), degraded coding of the signals, and clock errors. The contributions to the observables of the largest of these effects can be sharply reduced by application of suitable techniques (see, e.g., Blewitt ble90 ).

section.h3: 2.2 Obtaining the TEC from GPS data.

div.p: The GPS observable can be modeled as a function of distance from satellite to receiver, ionospheric delays, tropospheric delays, clock errors, and instrumental phase- and group-delay biases (Sardón et al. sar94 ). The ionospheric term can be estimated by a combination of the L1 and L2 observables. We can denote the TEC for any observation direction as Iki⁢(t)subscriptsuperscript𝐼𝑖𝑘𝑡italic-I POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)I^{i}_{k}(t). This TEC is defined along the line of sight from the radio telescope k𝑘italic-kk to the radio source i𝑖italic-ii and can be expressed approximately as a function 𝒱𝒱caligraphic-V\cal V (vertical value of TEC) of time t𝑡italic-tt and the intersection point Pkisubscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑖𝑘italic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:endP^{i}_{k} (“ionospheric point”) of the line of sight from k𝑘italic-kk to i𝑖italic-ii with the (average) F22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2} layer of the ionosphere (at an altitude of hF2=350subscriptℎsubscriptF2350italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:350h_{{\rm F}_{2}}=350 km), times the obliquity or slant function S⁢(eki)𝑆subscriptsuperscript𝑒𝑖𝑘italic-S OPEN:( italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)S(e^{i}_{k}), defined as the secant of the zenith angle at the ionospheric point (see below for geometry clarification), which is a function of the elevation angle ekisubscriptsuperscript𝑒𝑖𝑘italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:ende^{i}_{k} of the observation:

semantics.annotation: italic-I POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-S OPEN:( italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) MULOP:cdot caligraphic-V OPEN:( italic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: The positions of the involved sites and the ionospheric points can be expressed in a geocentric coordinate system (X,Y,Z)𝑋𝑌𝑍OPEN:( italic-X PUNCT:, italic-Y PUNCT:, italic-Z CLOSE:)(X,Y,Z) or in a geocentric-solar one (Ψ,χ,Z′)Ψ𝜒superscript𝑍′OPEN:( Psi PUNCT:, italic-chi PUNCT:, italic-Z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(\Psi,\chi,Z^{\prime}) with the Z′superscript𝑍′italic-Z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endZ^{\prime} axis directed toward the Sun from the Earth center, ΨΨPsi\Psi the angle in the X⁢Y𝑋𝑌italic-X italic-YXY-plane (measured counterclockwise from X𝑋italic-XX) and χ𝜒italic-chi\chi the angle with apex at the Earth’s center, measured from the direction to the Sun (Z′superscript𝑍′italic-Z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endZ^{\prime}) to the direction to Pjisubscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑖𝑗italic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:endP^{i}_{j}. This latter coordinate system is useful since the ionosphere is roughly time-independent in this reference frame. Following Sardón et al. (sar94 ), we replace 𝒱𝒱caligraphic-V\cal V for a GPS site j𝑗italic-jj and satellites l𝑙italic-ll by its locally linear approximation in Pjlsubscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑙𝑗italic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:endP^{l}_{j} (ionospheric point towards satellite l𝑙italic-ll) using the (Ψ,χ,Z′)Ψ𝜒superscript𝑍′OPEN:( Psi PUNCT:, italic-chi PUNCT:, italic-Z POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(\Psi,\chi,Z^{\prime})-coordinate system:

semantics.annotation: italic-I POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-S OPEN:( italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) MULOP:cdot OPEN:[ italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) italic-d Psi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) italic-d italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:] ADDOP:plus italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-K POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PERIOD:.

div.p: Here, the coefficients for each site are A𝐴italic-AA (0ththFLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start th FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{\rm th} order, vertical), B𝐵italic-BB (1ststFLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start st FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{\rm st} order, ΨΨPsi\Psi-direction), C𝐶italic-CC (1ststFLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start st FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{\rm st} order, χ𝜒italic-chi\chi-direction). We have also introduced the instrumental GPS satellite Klsuperscript𝐾𝑙italic-K POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endK^{l} and receiver Kjsubscript𝐾𝑗italic-K POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:endK_{j} biases. Aj⁢(t)subscript𝐴𝑗𝑡italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)A_{j}(t) is the vertical TEC at site j𝑗italic-jj, d⁢Ψjl⁢(t)=Ψjl-Ψj𝑑subscriptsuperscriptΨ𝑙𝑗𝑡subscriptsuperscriptΨ𝑙𝑗subscriptΨ𝑗italic-d Psi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals Psi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus Psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:endd\Psi^{l}_{j}(t)=\Psi^{l}_{j}-\Psi_{j}, and d⁢χjl=χjl-χj𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝜒𝑙𝑗subscript𝜒𝑗italic-d italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-chi POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-chi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:endd\chi^{l}_{j}=\chi^{l}_{j}-\chi_{j} are the coordinates ΨΨPsi\Psi and χ𝜒italic-chi\chi of the ionospheric point of the line of sight from j𝑗italic-jj towards the satellite l𝑙italic-ll minus the corresponding coordinates of the GPS site j𝑗italic-jj. The coefficients A𝐴italic-AA, B𝐵italic-BB, C𝐶italic-CC, can be determined, and the K𝐾italic-KK-biases largely removed, using a Kalman filtering method (Herring et al. her90 ) with the data from different satellites l𝑙italic-ll (about 8 at a time) to obtain an estimate of the TEC from GPS data. The K𝐾italic-KK biases can be due to such effects as errors in the estimation of phase ambiguities and multipath (see Sardón et al. sar94 ). In sum, we produce estimates of the total electron content of the ionosphere using data from a network of GPS stations and a multiplicity of satellites.

section.h2: 3 Vertical TEC from GPS and TEC for VLBI.

div.p: Here we describe the formulas we used to estimate the TEC along the paths of a VLBI observation from the values of the vertical TEC (evaluated by the method described in Sect. 2.2) at a GPS site near each one of the VLBI sites.

Consider a GPS site j𝑗italic-jj at latitude ζjsubscript𝜁𝑗italic-zeta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\zeta_{j} and longitude λjsubscript𝜆𝑗italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\lambda_{j}, and a VLBI site k𝑘italic-kk at position (ζk,λk)subscript𝜁𝑘subscript𝜆𝑘OPEN:( italic-zeta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(\zeta_{k},\lambda_{k}) (see Fig. 1). The coordinates of Pkisubscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑖𝑘italic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:endP^{i}_{k}, denoted by (ζPki,λPki)subscript𝜁subscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑖𝑘subscript𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑖𝑘OPEN:( italic-zeta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(\zeta_{P^{i}_{k}},\lambda_{P^{i}_{k}}) at the epoch the radio source is at elevation ekisubscriptsuperscript𝑒𝑖𝑘italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:ende^{i}_{k} and azimuth akisubscriptsuperscript𝑎𝑖𝑘italic-a POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda^{i}_{k}, are (Klobuchar klo87 ):

div.p: where (-π/2≤ζk≤π/2)𝜋2subscript𝜁𝑘𝜋2OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-zeta POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:)(-\pi/2\leq\zeta_{k}\leq\pi/2) and the arcsinOPFUNCTION:inverse-sine\arcsin-function in λ𝜆italic-lambda\lambda holds for values in the interval (-π/2,π/2)𝜋2𝜋2OPEN:( ADDOP:minus italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 CLOSE:)(-\pi/2,\pi/2), appropriate for Eq. (7) since GPS and VLBI sites are nearly collocated. ℰkisubscriptsuperscriptℰ𝑖𝑘caligraphic-E POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\cal E}^{i}_{k} is the angle, measured from the center of the Earth between the line to site k𝑘italic-kk and the line to the ionospheric point for radio source i𝑖italic-ii: ℰki=π/2-eki-arcsin⁡(Ξ⁢cos⁡eki)subscriptsuperscriptℰ𝑖𝑘𝜋2subscriptsuperscript𝑒𝑖𝑘Ξsubscriptsuperscript𝑒𝑖𝑘caligraphic-E POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-pi MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 ADDOP:minus italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus OPFUNCTION:inverse-sine OPEN:( Xi TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:){\cal E}^{i}_{k}=\pi/2-e^{i}_{k}-\arcsin(\Xi\cos e^{i}_{k}) (see Fig. 2, where Ξ=R⊕/(R⊕+hF2)Ξsubscript𝑅direct-sumsubscript𝑅direct-sumsubscriptℎsubscriptF2Xi RELOP:equals italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:direct-sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide OPEN:( italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:direct-sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\Xi=R_{\oplus}/(R_{\oplus}+h_{{\rm F}_{2}}), R⊕subscript𝑅direct-sumitalic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start ADDOP:direct-sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:endR_{\oplus} is the Earth’s radius, and Ξ≈0.948Ξ0.948Xi RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.948\Xi\approx 0.948 for hF2=350subscriptℎsubscriptF2350italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:350h_{{\rm F}_{2}}=350 km). The local time at the ionospheric point is t=(λPki/15)+𝑡limit-fromsubscript𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑖𝑘15italic-t RELOP:equals OPEN:( italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide NUMBER:15 CLOSE:) ADDOP:plust=(\lambda_{P^{i}_{k}}/15)+UT hr (λ𝜆italic-lambda\lambda in degrees, with λ𝜆italic-lambda\lambda positive to the East).

figure.figcaption: Figure 1: Geometry used to estimate TEC from GPS measurements (see text). The vertical lines here are radial (from the Earth’s center) and the tangent planes drawn are approximations to the surface of spheres (Earth and F22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2} layer of ionosphere) having, e.g., the VLBI site and its ionospheric point as points of tangency.

Figure 2: Geometry of the obliquity or slant factor, which is the secant of the zenith angle, defined by the elevation ekisubscriptsuperscript𝑒𝑖𝑘italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:ende^{i}_{k} (see text for definition of ΞΞXi\Xi). Curvatures of the Earth’s surface and the ionosphere F22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2} layer are exaggerated for clarity.

div.p: We assume that the vertical TEC APki⁢(t)subscript𝐴subscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑖𝑘𝑡italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)A_{P^{i}_{k}}(t) at the ionospheric point is given in terms of Aj⁢(t)subscript𝐴𝑗𝑡italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)A_{j}(t) by:

semantics.annotation: italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t ADDOP:plus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:15 ARG:end CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: This relation effects a longitude correction but ignores any latitude dependence of the TEC values. This approach is reasonable for mid-latitude stations and sources at high declination since GPS sites can be collocated with VLBI sites, or at least placed relatively near to them, and since TEC changes more rapidly with longitude than with latitude.

The slant factor was defined above as the secant of the zenith angle, which is arcsin⁡(Ξ⁢cos⁡eki)Ξsubscriptsuperscript𝑒𝑖𝑘OPFUNCTION:inverse-sine OPEN:( Xi TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)\arcsin(\Xi\cos e^{i}_{k}) (see Fig. 2, and Klobuchar klo87 ). Thus, the TEC at the ionospheric point Pkisubscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑖𝑘italic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:endP^{i}_{k}, mapped by the slant factor (Eq. 4) gives

semantics.annotation: italic-I POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals TRIGFUNCTION:secant OPEN:{ OPFUNCTION:inverse-sine OPEN:( Xi TRIGFUNCTION:cosine italic-e POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) CLOSE:} MULOP:cdot italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) PUNCT:,

div.p: which, with Eq. (2) yields our estimate of the ionospheric delays at the indicated VLBI site. The overall ionospheric effect on a VLBI observable is a simple linear combination of the effects from each of the two sites involved in the observation.

section.h2: 4 A case to test the method: VLBI observations of the Draco triangle.

div.p: Progress in high precision phase-delay difference astrometry has been made by Ros et al. (ros99 ) through VLBI observations of triangle formed by the radio sources BL 1803+784, QSO 1928+738 and BL 2007+777, in the Northern constellation of Draco (the Dragon). The observations were made simultaneously at the frequencies of 2.3 and 8.4 GHz at epoch 1991.89 with an intercontinental interferometric array. The angular separations among these radio sources were determined with submilliarcsecond accuracy from a weighted-least-squares analysis of the differenced and undifferenced phase delays. The modeling of these astrometric VLBI observations was sufficiently accurate to estimate reliably the “2⁢π2𝜋NUMBER:2 italic-pi2\pi ambiguities” in the differenced phase delays for source separations of almost 7∘FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{\circ} on the sky. For such angular distances, this accurate “phase connection” at 8.4 GHz, yielding the phase delays with standard errors well within one phase cycle over the entire session of observations, was demonstrated at an epoch of solar maximum. As in earlier works (e.g., Guirado et al. gui95 , Lara et al. lar96 ), after phase connection the effects of the extended structure of the radio sources were largely removed from the phase-delay observables. The effects of the ionosphere were also mostly removed, via the GPS-based method described in this paper.

In 1991 the number of available GPS sites was small, and only data from Goldstone and Pinyon Flats in the US, and from Herstmonceux and Wettzell in Europe (see Table 1 for details) were available to be used for our experiment. GPS data from the two US sites were used for the VLBI sites at Fort Davis (TX), Pie Town (NM), Kitt Peak (AZ), and Los Alamos (NM) to estimate the TEC for observations at these sites. Similarly, GPS data from both European sites were used for Effelsberg (Germany). The VLBI observations were carried out from 14 hr UT on 20 November to 4 hr UT on 21 November 1991. In Fig. 3 we show the corresponding vertical TEC values for one of the GPS sites on each continent. We see the dusk and night part of the data for Wettzell, and the daylight data for Pinyon Flats.

figure.figcaption: Table 1: Positions of the GPS sites and the VLBI sites (Ros et al. ros99 ) and maximum and minimum values of the vertical TEC value on 20/21 November 1991 (see text for definitions of notation).

semantics.annotation: italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start min POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end
italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start max POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end

figure.figcaption: Figure 3: Values of the vertical TEC at the GPS sites of Pinyon Flats (CA, US) and Wettzell (Germany) (Ros et al. 1999). These values were used to compute the TECs at nearby VLBI sites. We assumed an error of 1.5 TECU (represented by the dotted lines), much larger than the statistical standard errors.

div.p: From the GPS-based estimates of the TEC along the lines of sight for each VLBI site, we calculated the ionospheric contribution for each baseline and epoch of observation. These ionospheric contributions were removed from the VLBI observables. For the phase delays, these contributions ranged in magnitude from 0 to 1.2 ns at 8.4 GHz for intercontinental baselines, and were less than 0.1 ns for continental baselines. The intercontinental baseline lengths range from ∼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim7800 to ∼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim8300 km, and the differences in local time are ∼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim7.5 hr (see Fig. 3). Since the ionospheric effect is the combination of effects for both antennas, the ionospheric delay is quite important for our intercontinental baselines. By contrast our US-continental baseline lengths range from ∼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim200 to ∼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim750 km which corresponds at most to about 30 minutes difference in local time and a much smaller ionospheric effect on the VLBI observables.

Eq. (3) provides the usual way to largely remove the effect of the ionosphere on dual-band VLBI observations. The phase delays from our 2.3 GHz observations could not be freed from 2⁢π2𝜋NUMBER:2 italic-pi2\pi ambiguities due to the large scatter in these data. However, unambiguous but less precise group delays were available at both 2.3 and 8.4 GHz. The ionospheric contributions were estimated from these group-delay data. In Fig. 4 we show the comparison of GPS-based and dual-band VLBI-based ionospheric delay estimates at 8.4 GHz. We show four of the ten available baselines as representative examples: two intercontinental and two continental-US ones. Apart from the larger dispersion in the group-delay than in the GPS-based data, this comparison provides a good independent confirmation of the reliability of the GPS-based method for the correction of VLBI data. The error bars for the group delays shown in the figure are the appropriate combination of the statistical standard errors for the data at these frequencies (see Eq. 3). The statistical standard errors for the GPS estimates are each about 0.2 TECU. We assume a much larger standard error –1.5 TECU– to try to account for possible inaccuracies not estimated with the Kalman filtering, such as incorrect values for hF2subscriptℎsubscriptF2italic-h POSTSUBSCRIPT:start F POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:endh_{{\rm F}_{2}}, the consequent changes in the mapping function and in the eventual position of the ionospheric point, and other unmodeled effects. Thus, we infer a corresponding contribution of ∼similar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim30 ps to the standard errors of the phase delays at 8.4 GHz. For the data presented in Fig. 4, the root-mean-square of the differences between the results from the two methods are below 0.15 ns for intercontinental baselines and 0.10 ns for continental ones.

figure.figcaption: Figure 4: Comparison between the ionospheric delays at 8.4 GHz estimated by the combination of group delays at 8.4 and 2.3 GHz from the VLBI observations of Ros et al. (ros99 ) (points with error bars) and the corresponding ionospheric delays estimated by the GPS TEC determination reported here (solid line). Data from four representative baselines of a total of ten from the VLBI experiment are shown here. Root-mean-square values for the differences are, respectively, of 0.11, 0.15, for the upper panels and of 0.10, 0.08 ns for the lower panels.

div.p: Assuming that the ionosphere can be modeled usefully as a thin shell surrounding the Earth at a height of 350 km, we estimate the TEC for the line of sight from the GPS site to the satellite using ground reception of GPS signals and knowledge of the orbital parameters of the GPS satellites. Having a GPS site near a VLBI site, we can reliably “transfer” this estimate to the TEC for the line of sight from the radio telescope to the radio source. These TEC values allow us to correct the VLBI observables for the effects of the ionosphere for any frequency. We made such corrections for our phase-delay data at 8.4 GHz (Ros et al. ros99 ) for an epoch at which there was a paucity of relevant GPS data. The estimates of the ionospheric delays provided by the VLBI measurements of group delay at 2.3 and 8.4 GHz differ from the corresponding delays obtained from GPS data to within root-mean-square values below 0.15 ns for intercontinental baselines and 0.10 ns for continental ones. Thus, we have shown, in particular, that the GPS determination of TEC can be successfully used in the astrometric analysis of VLBI observations.

The density of the network of GPS sites has increased dramatically since 1991 and the accuracy of the TEC deduced from GPS data has improved significantly. Given such progress, the approximations used in this paper are no longer necessary. Now GPS estimates for the vertical TEC are available from virtually every land location all of the time and thus for every VLBI observation.

The advantages of GPS compared with geostationary beacons which used Faraday rotation to determine TECs are notable: global land coverage for GPS is available from geodetic networks (e.g., the International GPS Geodynamics Service); the TEC estimates do not depend on assumptions about the Earth’s magnetic field; L1 and L2 GPS data are available over the internet in standard formats (e.g., RINEX: Receiver INdependent EXchange). We also note that the ionosphere cannot always be represented by a thin shell model with good accuracy; moreover, more accurate models can be devised and suitably parameterized given the tomography-like sampling of the ionosphere provided by the GPS. The biases in the GPS observables have to be properly corrected in the estimates of TECs. Davies & Hartmann (dav97 ) set an upper limit of 3 TECU for the present agreement of GPS TEC with the results from other methods, but only of few 0.01 TECU for the relative errors of TEC estimates over the course of some hours for any given site. The latter represents relative changes of delay at 8.4 GHz of 0.2 ps, nearly two orders of magnitude smaller than the delay equivalent of a 2⁢π2𝜋NUMBER:2 italic-pi2\pi phase ambiguity. With such accuracies and the present network of GPS sites, the removal of most of the effect of the ionosphere from VLBI observations should not be difficult, although much of the smaller-scale ionospheric activity cannot be adequately sampled by GPS. From dual-band difference VLBI astrometry and GPS data, the optical depth of the emission in radio sources can be better studied by comparing brightness distributions obtained independently at each frequency band with respect to the same coordinate system. In sum, the introduction of GPS techniques should greatly improve the scientific results obtained from VLBI observations.

section.div: Acknowledgements.E.R. acknowledges a F.P.I. fellowship of the Generalitat Valenciana. We acknowledge the referee, Dr. R.M. Campbell for his very helpful suggestions and remarks. We are grateful to the SOPAC/IGPP, at SIO, University of California, San Diego (US), for kindly providing the GPS data from their GARNER archives, and to Prof. R.T. Schilizzi for encouragement. This work has been partially supported by the Spanish DGICYT grants PB 89-0009, PB 93-0030, and PB 96-0782, and by the U.S. National Science Foundation Grant No. AST 89-02087.
